notch.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: a level on a scale that measures something, for example quality or achievement
notch.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Her new book is several notches above anything else she has written.
Jackson raised his voice by a notch.
The Spartans turned it up a notch in the second half.
notch.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: a V-shaped cut or hole in a surface or edge
notch.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Cut a notch near one end of the stick.
notch.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: a passage between two mountains or hills
notch.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to cut a V-shaped mark into something, especially as a way of showing the number of times something has been done
notch.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: a degree or level on a scale that measures achievement, price etc
notch.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: The Federal Reserve is expected to reduce interest rates another notch.
The 500-stock index gained 0.43 to 358.43, a notch below the record close of 359.80.
notch.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: to obtain or achieve something important or something that gives you an advantage over other people
notch.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: Boeing quickly notched 49 firm orders for the new plane.
Mutual funds that hold stocks in smaller companies havenotched up hugegains.
